FlagsNZ,"2014-08-17T09:00:07.197Z","A fantastic new theme for Lego","

As soon as I saw this set heading for Project Review I hoped that it would be accepted by Lego.
It was the astronomy theme that hooked me.
I was drawn to the originality of this Idea and impressed that it was not based on a licensed theme.
There is something special about the Ideas box. It is printed black inside which makes it seem different than regular Lego boxes.
The instruction book is also of a superior quality. It is a stapled booklet printed on better quality paper.

column1:
,TRUE,5,5,5,5,5 brunonowak","2015-01-03T19:53:00.663Z","Unique inspiring Ideas set especially for parents of girls","

I was finally able to buy and build the Research Institute. At the time of this review I have an 8YO girl and as the parent of a girl that gets bombarded with stereotypes about what girls are supposed to be like in childhood and adulthood it is very cool and refreshing to see a set like this come to life.

The box is well designed, with higher end materials and finish as is the standard for Lego Ideas sets. The instructions are also the high end booklet with an introduction about the ideator and details about each of the professions "
There are only a few unique parts in this set from my experience:
- The printed blackboard for the Astronomer
- The Erlenmeyer flasks for the Chemist (you get a green and a purple one)

Besides those there are quite a few rare parts in interesting colors like the pieces that make up the telescope and the skeleton. You also get some 1x1 tiles and a few interesting transparent ones for the Chemist lab.
All 3 minifigures are very detailed and only the Astronomer doesn'
column2: t get any back print. All 3 minifigs have two different faces (on calm/concentrated the other one worried/stressed). I really like the way the prints are done as they depict different dressing styles for different professions making (my interpretation) the point that you can have your own personal style in any profession of your choice (most of the time).

column1: The build was fun and the set came in a bag for each of the professions. The one I liked the most was the Paleontologist as the dinosaur'
column2: s skeleton was a lot of fun to build and understand the pieces used to present such an accurate and good looking specimen in such a small scale. Kudos to Alatariel for that.
re finished with the build you can play a bit with it (especially if you have kids or are a kid yourself - regardless of age above 5-6YO) and there&#39
column3: s plenty of opportunity for roleplay and interaction with other sets or MOCs you may have (I can see myself playing with my daughter with the 3 scientists going to a conference using the airport set we have). It would be harded to include this in play with Friends sets (which my daughter really likes) due to the different minifig sizes but I guess that is ok and expected.

set into the Science and Research fields for Lego that left me wanting more. I hope the finished Natural History Museum fills that gap very soon. Highly recommended for kids to play with as much as for adults to have on display.

column13: >LEGO Ideas is not just about making new Licensed Properties in on-off sets based on the designs of fans. It is also about interesting builds or fun little vignettes made by fans to introduce different ideas and elements to fans of LEGO. This was a very well received set from the LEGO Ideas name, which was praised simply because of its empowerment message to young girls. Is it really a great set though? We shall see.

column8: >Box: A much smaller box compared to the Ghostbusters set, this box has a nice looking design with some hexagonal shapes on a dark grey background with a larger hexagon showcasing the Vignette models included in the set. The back shows each Vignette with the name of each character and their little sets to display them with. It&rsquo
column9: s a plainer design, but nevertheless quite impressive.

column8: >Instructions: The manual is very much in keeping with manuals found in LEGO Ideas sets. The problems however in this one is that the build has very little to do and so we shall find this one to be the shortest number of pages to date from my reviews of these sets. It isn&rsquo
column9: t terrible, it is however noticeable as the instructions don&rsquo
column10: t have as many detailed bits of history or trivia as the licensed properties include.

column8: >There are still the pages explaining the designers idea and the set in general, there are just a lot less to read when looking through the book.
>The parts in this set are definitely useful for making Vignettes if you wanted, however aside from the printed chalkboard, the sextant or the grey pail used in the telescope build I don&rsquo
column9: t see very many unique pieces here. The 6x6 plates used as bases for the Vignette set pieces may also be good.

column8: >Astronomer: This is a decent enough looking Minifigure. Honestly like with most LEGO City based sets the design is simple and doesn&rsquo
column9: t include anything unique, the torso print is single sided and may be brand new here, but the head being double-sided is I believe a re-use of prints found in the LEGO Movie theme. She has no accessories to her trade.

column8: >Chemist: Wearing a lab coat with a name tag on it I believe she is using a brand new torso print, which is very impressive looking. Her head however is another print that is re-used from the LEGO movie line I believe Executive Ellen used it. Her hair piece has been seen many times in the CMF line, for accessories she includes a beaker and the small additional container build from a half cylinder piece or cone piece with a stud.
>Paleontologist: Also receiving a double-sided torso print, this woman is wearing some kind of sweater or blouse that doesn&rsquo
column9: t exactly scream paleontologist. This was definitely a new print though as it includes a shell necklace that resembles an ammonite shell. She includes the movie star actress head from the LEGO Movie theme and has a magnifying glass accessory.

column8: >Bag 1: Each build is designed to fit on a 6x6 plate. Making a nice little Vignette for the Minifigure showing them interacting with each element. For this bag you are building the scene for the Chemist, which features a small work station, drawers and bottles soon to be filled with chemical brews for scientific study. The build is quick and easy to follow, there aren&rsquo
column9: t any really tricky parts, which confuses me as to why this set was listed as only 10+ builders. Younger builders shouldn&rsquo
column10: t have too many troubles with this first bag, the dinosaur skeleton might be a bit more troublesome though.

column9: s the Paleontologists set piece, and as noted the skeleton is a much more involved build compared to the other two Vignettes found in this set. It&rsquo
column10: s a very clever build, though not to scale considering the LEGO T-Rex piece is a much larger model. Perhaps the skeleton found by this paleontologist was of a juvenile, not yet fully grown. A microscope mini-model is also include for examining bones, it&rsquo
column11: s a fast little build too with more SNOT techniques.

column8: >Bag 3: This third build is a much less detailed Vignette, the build involves very little compared to the t-rex skeleton and can be completed in less than thirty minutes with a fast enough builder. The floor is made up of mostly alternating 1x1 tiles to simulated a tiled floor, it&rsquo
column9: s a very nice technique that I haven&rsquo
column10: t seen used often outside of Modulars. The telescope build is also quite impressive.

column9: s Vignette: This is a little chemical desk area. The model features very few pieces for building up the cabinets and the chemical bottles. I feel it&rsquo
column10: s the weakest of the three areas due to the lack of proper tools or anything that really stands out. The features of the model are decent, however I feel it could have used a bit more to actually do.

column9: s Vignette: This is one of the better offerings of the small models from this set. It consists of two separate elements, a very clever standing microscope build which is very fun looking and a nifty dinosaur skeleton. I just adore the skeleton here because it is the largest use of pieces and includes very clever design elements. There are no visible studs in this build either except for inside the mouth and the eyes. Naturally the floor is all visible studs, but the main model itself just really embraces SNOT.
s Vignette: This model is also very clever, there&rsquo
column10: s a chalkboard, which is a printed piece and a very impressive looking telescope. The tiles on the floor are just the icing on the cake here and I honestly feel that this could have been larger to include even more great elements if the model wasn&rsquo
column11: t conformed to the tiny vignette style.

column8: >Despite not having much to say about the models I have to say this is a very nice looking Ideas set. It has some flaws, there&rsquo
column9: s very little to do here for play features. It&rsquo
column10: s obviously meant for display only, which isn&rsquo
column11: t a bad thing because all of the vignettes look great as display pieces. Unfortunately this means younger builders may not appreciate it as much as the older collectors. Considering it sold out relatively quickly however I&rsquo
column12: d say this set is definitely a good one and one I would strongly recommend if you can find it.

column1:
,TRUE,3,3,3,3,3 DrFrankenstein","2015-12-19T18:39:26.27Z","More inspired than all of the Friends sets together","

When LEGO released the female scientists set (aka Research Institute), I managed to grab a copy as a gift to my scientist wife and it hit the spot perfectly. She very much enjoyed putting together the models in the set and liked very much the realistic portrayal of women working in research. The chemical lab in particular resembled very closely the lab that she works in.
The finished models look very nice and are different from each other (I haven'
column2: t built the models in the set myself, so I can&#39
column3: t comment on the built itself). Not only there is a lot of creative use of bricks in each model, but also the end results are stable and don&#39
column4: t fall apart the moment one touches them. While my wife likes the chem lab the most (it had lots of beakers, syringes, and other props on the shelve and in the drawers), my favorite mini-set here is the dinosaur, which is really creative in its construction and parts use. The front support rod locks the skeleton in a stable position, just like a real museum display. Another nice part here is the magnifying glass held by the paleontologist, which actually contains a real lens.

column1: The overall presentation of the set is very appealing. The box and booklet are printed on high-quality cardboard and paper - noticeably better than the usual LEGO products. I like how the booklet gives background on Dr. Ellen Kooijman and the scientific disciplines portrayed by the set. Definitely a nice gift set.
The Research Institute set is very unique and bold in its portrayal of working women. I don'
column2: t think that I have seen anything similar amongst the LEGO products. While LEGO has a number of lines that are great for boys, its attempts to make themes for girls are not particularly inspired. The Friends theme, modeled after the Barbie and Bratz dolls universe, portrays life as a mix of pastel-colored beauty and leisure supporting the stereotype that &quot
column3: all that girls want is fun&quot
column4: . These sets have no hints of leadership, professional development, challenging the world. Fine if you are happy to go with the Disney princess flow, but certainly not something that will inspire your little princess to look beyond the castle. The Research Institute completely breaks this mold and gives a totally opposite take on what women are capable of. Now this is a set that parents can give their little girls knowing that it delivers inspired female role models, and keeps the bubble-headed bimbos away. I hope that LEGO releases more of these sets in the future.
